awd_titl_txt: Implementation Project: Graduation Academy - Transitioning STEM Students to Graduation and Graduate School
awd_abstract_narration:
The Implementation project entitled: Graduation Academy - Transitioning STEM Students to Graduation and Graduate School at Norfolk State University builds on two successful previous implementation projects which resulted in significant gains in freshmen retention, in an innovative learning-living community and a comprehensive peer mentoring center. However, the progression of students from the sophomore level to the junior level has not been replicated at the institution. This project investigates multiple strategies to address that problem that is not uncommon for members of underrepresented groups. The Graduation Academy will feature a Sophomore summer bridge program, a Sophomore/Junior year prep program, a Graduation Academy for transfer students, Junior/Senior transition week, mentoring, scholarships and undergraduate research, and faculty development.

A comprehensive evaluative process will produce insights into the challenges, best practices, and measures of anticipated outcomes. The evaluation plan will be based on the triangulation approach utilizing mixed-methods data gathering strategies of both qualitative and quantitative data. 

The project will increase the number and quality of students from underrepresented groups who earn undergraduate degrees in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM), pursue graduate study, and/or enter the STEM workforce. The summative evaluation will provide a view of the entire project, longitudinal progression toward project goals, and lessons learned in retaining and graduating underrepresented groups in STEM disciplines.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
Implementation Project: Graduation Academy - Transitioning STEM Students to Graduation and Graduate School

 

Norfolk State University (NSU) is a Historically Black College and University that serves approximately 5400 + students of which 1,783 are enrolled in the College of Science, Engineering, and Technology (CSET), which offers degree programs in Biology, Chemistry, Computer Science, Engineering, Mathematics, Physics, and Technology. Despite the significant gain in our freshmen retention, progression of our students from sophomore to junior level has not been duplicated. NSU has established a new project, entitled: ?Graduation Academy: Transitioning STEM Students to Graduation and Graduate School.? This new project focuses on the development of STEM majors at the sophomore, junior, and senior levels, building upon the great success of other STEM programs at NSU. There are multiple strategies required to meet or overcome this unique and persistent problem. The academy consists of the following features: a Sophomore/Junior Summer Bridge Program, b) Sophomore/Junior Year Prep Program, c) Scholarships and Undergraduate Research, d) Graduate School Prep, and e) Faculty Development.

The new project encourages and support the participation of students from underrepresented groups in scientific meetings and activities of professional societies. A cascading mentoring component between undergraduate students, graduate students, and faculty provides the interactions and community to help ensure successful outcomes. The project main objective was to increase the matriculation rate of students from sophomore to junior years by the third fall semester. 

Sophomore/Junior Summer Bridge Program

To increase the STEM student success rate, Graduation Academy students participated in an enhanced Summer Bridge Program where mathematics was one of the main key features of the program. This discipline specific program was designed to prepare rising sophomore and junior students majoring in STEM for their sophomore and junior year where academic competencies required in the junior and senior year are required.

The finding from the Sophomore/Junior Summer Bridge survey revealed that overall students believed the program help them identify math skills that they were really good at demonstrating (100%) as well as those needing improvement (100%). In addition, the rising sophomore students indicated that the information was appropriate for preparing them for their major courses in the coming year and felt more confident in their ability to do well in their upcoming year?s coursework (100%). Over 90% of the students were very satisfied or somewhat satisfied with the level of interaction with faculty and other students, and teaching strategies used in the class sessions.  89% indicated they were satisfied with the math content and 83% were satisfied with the discipline specific content covered.

Sophomore/Junior Prep Program

A Sophomore/Junior Prep Program was established offered unique departmental workshops by discipline for STEM students held during the held from August through May of each academic year. Lead master faculty from each STEM academic department programs, called Graduation Academy Coordinators (GAC), who teach the sophomore or junior level major courses. The activities coordinated and implemented by the GACs included mentoring, seminars, tutoring, and social bonding activities. The sophomores and juniors were encouraged and supported to travel to conferences, graduate school open houses, and attend at least three bonding activities held during the fall and spring semesters. The findings from the Sophomore/Junior Prep survey, students became more involved in departmental activities, thus affording them the opportunities to build better relationships with their departmental faculty and receive information regarding curriculum updates, departmental research opportunities, scholarships, summer internships, and graduate/professional schools. Those students who participated overwhelmingly thought the program to be helpful and encouraging.

Graduation Academy Undergraduate Research Program

NSU students was actively involved in conducting undergraduate research to advance their STEM knowledge beyond the scope of classroom material. This program provided intellectual challenges and experiences in the scientific methods of investigations, problem solving, and state-of-art experimental procedures, independent as well as teamwork. Students were required to a) work collaboratively with a faculty research mentor during the academic year and/or during the summer, b) participate in an end-of the semester technical oral or presentation during the academic year; presenting weekly progress reports during the summer session, c) deliver a technical presentation at a regional and/or national STEM conference, d) prepare an oral/poster presentation and final technical report. The Graduation Academy Undergraduate Research experience served as an umbrella to several other research programs within CSET at NSU.

 As an additional resource to our students, we included undergraduate research opportunities for approximately 12 juniors and seniors, not only during the summer, but during the academic year (fall and spring). Undergraduate research stipends were provided to students to reduce the number of STEM majors seeking outside employment during the academic year. Undergraduate Research is a proven method to increase retention, strengthen preparation for graduate school, and enhance critical thinking skills. The Graduation Academy Undergraduate Research Program provided students these opportunities and more. 

 


Last Modified: 01/04/2022
Modified by: Aliecia Mcclain
